  }}| Section8 = {{Chembox Related
|   OtherAnions = OtherCations = OtherCpds = Cytosine; Adenine; Thymine; Uracil
  }} }} 'Guanine' ('G, Gua') is one of the four main nucleobases found in the
  nucleic acids DNA and RNA, the others being adenine, cytosine, and thymine
  (uracil in RNA). In DNA, guanine is paired with cytosine. With the formula
  C 5H 5N 5O, guanine is a derivative of purine,
  consisting of a fused pyrimidine-imidazole ring system with conjugated double
  bonds. Being unsaturated, the bicyclic molecule is planar. The guanine
  nucleoside is called guanosine.
